title: Gear Second Development Timeline
theoryText: Fans theorize about when exactly Luffy developed Gear Second. Some believe he conceptualized it during the sea train journey to Enies Lobby after witnessing CP9's Rokushiki techniques, particularly Soru (Shave). Others think he had been working on it since his devastating defeat by Admiral Aokiji, constantly thinking about how to become stronger to protect his crew. The technique seems to be inspired by observing how CP9 members enhance their physical abilities through Rokushiki.
author: One Piece Fan Community
evidence: Luffy mentions his defeat by Aokiji as motivation to become stronger
The timing suggests development during or after the sea train journey
Luffy's explanation shows understanding of his rubber body's capabilities
The technique mimics aspects of Soru (rapid movement)

title: Gear Second as Response to Aokiji Trauma
theoryText: This theory posits that Gear Second was born directly from Luffy's traumatic encounter with Admiral Aokiji, where Luffy realized he was completely powerless to protect his crew. Fans note that the episode emphasizes protecting friends in its title, and Luffy's internal monologue often references not letting his crew be hurt again. Gear Second represents Luffy's first self-developed power-up specifically designed to bridge the gap between himself and admiral-level opponents.
author: One Piece Theory Community
evidence: Episode title: 'Everything Is to Protect My Friends!'
Luffy's determination to never lose a crewmate again
The power-up appears specifically when facing World Government forces
Thematic connection to the Aokiji defeat

title: Rubber Physiology Makes Gear Second Unique
theoryText: Fans theorize that Gear Second is only possible because of Luffy's rubber body - specifically, his rubber cardiovascular system can withstand the extreme pressure of accelerated blood flow that would kill a normal person. This theory suggests that Luffy's understanding of his Devil Fruit has evolved from simple stretching to manipulating his internal biology. The technique represents a major leap in creative Devil Fruit usage, inspiring later theories about Devil Fruit 'awakening' being tied to understanding one's power at a fundamental level.
author: One Piece Science Community
evidence: Luffy's explanation of pumping blood faster
Visual representation of steam from metabolic heat
Rob Lucci later compares it to doping in the manga
The technique wouldn't work without rubber blood vessels

title: Gear Second Inspired by CP9's Rokushiki
theoryText: This theory suggests Luffy developed Gear Second by observing and adapting CP9's Rokushiki techniques, particularly Soru. Fans note that Blueno even comments that Luffy's speed resembles Soru during the fight. Rather than learning Rokushiki directly, Luffy created his own method to achieve similar results using his Devil Fruit powers. This demonstrates Luffy's combat genius - he doesn't copy techniques, but understands the principles and adapts them to his unique abilities.
author: Combat Analysis Community
evidence: Blueno's comment about Luffy matching Soru speed
Timing coincides with exposure to CP9
Luffy's history of adapting observed techniques
Manga panel where Luffy observes CP9 movements

title: The Symbolism of Steam and Burning Passion
theoryText: Beyond the biological explanation, fans theorize that the steam rising from Luffy's body during Gear Second carries symbolic weight. The steam represents Luffy's burning passion and determination to save Robin - his willpower literally manifesting as visible heat. This theory connects to the broader One Piece theme that willpower and determination can manifest as physical phenomena (later confirmed with Haki). The pink/red coloring of Luffy's skin isn't just from blood flow, but represents his burning emotions.
author: Thematic Analysis Community
evidence: Episode title emphasizing protecting friends
Visual emphasis on steam in animation
Connection to later Haki concepts
One Piece's history of visual metaphors for determination

title: Gear Second Foreshadows Future Power-Ups
theoryText: Fans theorize that Gear Second's debut establishes a pattern for Luffy's future development - each 'Gear' represents Luffy pushing his Devil Fruit and body in new creative ways. The fact that Luffy acknowledges his body can't fully handle Gear Second yet foreshadows both the technique's drawbacks and his eventual mastery. Some fans predicted the existence of Gear Third, Gear Fourth, and even Gear Fifth based on this episode establishing the 'Gear' naming convention and Luffy's tendency to overcome limitations.

evidence: The 'Gear' naming convention suggesting a series
Luffy's comment about his body not handling it perfectly
